Above all nations is humanity | aba profile = }} The '''William S. Richardson School of Law''' is a public, co-educational institution of the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawai{{okina}}i at MÄnoa]] in [[Honolulu, Hawaii|Honolulu, Hawai{{okina}}i]]. Named after the beloved [[Hawaii State Supreme Court|Hawai{{okina}}i State Supreme Court]] [[Chief Justice]] [[William S. Richardson]], it is the only law school in the [[Hawaii|State of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. The Law School has been accredited by the Council of the Section of Legal Education and Admissions to the Bar of the American Bar Association since 1982. The Law School has been a member of the Association of American Law Schools (AALS) since 1989. The William S. Richardson School of Law has adopted a mission of promoting justice, ethical responsibility and public service with special emphasis on fields of law of particular importance to [[Hawaii|Hawai{{okina}}i]] and the [[Pacific Rim]] region including [[environmental law]], rights of [[Native Hawaiians]], [[maritime law]] and [[Pacific]] and [[Asia]]n legal systems. There are approximately 326 students. Entering classes include approximately 90 full-time students and 24 part-time students. ==Establishment== The William S. Richardson School of Law was established by an act of the [[Hawaii State Legislature|Hawai{{okina}}i State Legislature]] in 1968 and welcomed its first [[Juris Doctor|doctor of jurisprudence]] candidates in 1973. There were 53 students in the first class, including [[John D. Waihee III]], future [[Governor of Hawaii|Governor of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. In 1974, the American Bar Association granted provisional accreditation and then full accreditation in 1982. In 1983, the William S. Richardson School of Law moved into new facilities on the campus of the University of Hawai{{okina}}i at MÄnoa. ==Recent Developments== *In 2003, Avi Soifer became the law school dean.{{cite news|last=Espanol|first=Zenaida Serrano|title=Nominee for UH law dean approved|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2003/Mar/15/ln/ln14a.html|accessdate=9/27/2011|newspaper=Honolulu Advertiser|date=03/15/2003}} *Ka Huli Ao Center for Excellence in Native Hawaiian Law[http://www.law.hawaii.edu/kahuliao Ka Huli Ao website] was established in 2005 through a ''Native Hawaiian Education Act'' grant. Melody L. MacKenzie, a graduate of the first graduating class of the school and the longest-serving legal clerk to the school's namesake, directs the Center. *The Law School established an evening law program in Fall 2008.{{cite news|title=UH Law School to launch part-time programs|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Dec/10/br/br8465319720.html|accessdate=09/27/2011|newspaper=Honolulu Advertiser|date=12/10/2007}} *Chief Justice William S. Richardson passed away peacefully on June 21, 2010.{{cite news|last=Hevesi|first=Dennis|title=William S. Richardson, 90; Led Hawaii Court|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B01E3D9133BF93BA15755C0A9669D8B63&ref=dennis_hevesi|accessdate=09/27/2011|newspaper=New York Times|date=06/28/2010}} ==Rankings== *The Law School scored high in two recent law school rankings -- 16th for Top Law School Clinical Opportunities on the 2011 ''National Jurist'' list {{cite news|last=Weyenberg|first=Michelle|title=Top law school for clinical opportunities|url=http://www.nxtbook.com/nxtbooks/cypress/nationaljurist0911/index.php?startid=26#/24|accessdate=09/27/2011|newspaper=National Jurist|date=09/2011}} and one of the top 60 Best Value Law Schools in ''preLaw Magazine.''{{cite news|title=Best Value law schools for 2011 dominated by public schools|url=http://www.nationaljurist.com/content/best-value-law-schools-2011-dominated-public-schools|accessdate=09/27/2011|newspaper=preLawt|date=08/22/2011}} *''The Princeton Review'' ranked the Law School as number one in the United States for "Best Environment for Minority Students", fifth for "Most Diverse Faculty", and seventh for "Most Welcoming of Older Students" in its 2011 edition of the ''Best Law Schools''.{{cite web|title=University of Hawaii at Manoa William S. Richardson School of Law|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/UniversityofHawaiiatManoaSchoolofLaw.aspx|publisher=''Princeton Review''|accessdate=09/27/2011}} *In 2011, ''U.S. News & World Report'' ranked Richardson 95th of 190 Law Schools (the smallest school in the Top 100).{{cite web|title=University of Hawaii--Manoa (Richardson)|url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-law-schools/university-of-hawaii-manoa-richardson-03043|publisher=''U.S. News & World Report''|accessdate=09/27/2011}} ==U.S. Supreme Court Jurists-in-Residence Program== *U.S. Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito visited the Law School in Spring of 2011 as part of the school's Jurist-in-Residence program.{{cite news|last=Chiem|first=Linda|title=Legal community gets access to Justice Alito in January|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/print-edition/2010/11/19/legal-community-gets-access-to-justice.html|accessdate=9/27/2011|newspaper=Pacific Business News|date=11/19/2010}} *For a complete list of jurists-in-residence, please see the Law School website - http://www.law.hawaii.edu/us-supreme-court-jurist-residence-program ==Moot Court Competitions== *On February 26, 2011, third year law students Keani Alapa and Maxwell Kopper clinched First Place in the Best Advocate category (formerly known as Best Overall). The Hawai{{okina}}i duo competed against Briana Coyla and Andy Murphy from the University of Washington. Second year law student Elika Stimpson won Third Place Best Oralist in a tie with Sherri Mitchell from the University of Arizona. Jeannin Russo and Mark Jensen, two other Hawai{{okina}}i third year law students, competed in the semi-final round bringing the Hawai{{okina}}i law school's presence to one-half of the top four teams in the competition.
